userInterface
Class GameEngine

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          javax.swing.JComponent
              javax.swing.JPanel
                  userInterface.GameEngine
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Runnable, javax.accessibility.Accessible
public class GameEngine
extends javax.swing.JPanel
implements java.lang.Runnable

This class acts as the game engine. It's the responsible of the updating, rendering, and drawing Sprite processes. This three processes are continuosly excecuted in a separated Thread, causing them to be other game processes independent (if a non updating state is desired, it should be caused by setting the updatables field to an empty updatables arrayList or overriding the update() method from the updatables with control variables). This Thread is started when the GameEngine is added to a GameFrame or a GameApplet. The rendering tecnique implemented is Active Rendering, handling the possibility of controlling the frames per second rate at the choice of the user. *

See Also:
Serialized Form

Method Detail

instantiate

public static GameEngine instantiate()
This method is used to get a GameEngine instance following the Single-Town model

Returns:
a GameEngine instance

startEngine

protected void startEngine()
This method checks if the animator field is null. If it is, the GameEngine will assignate a new Thread to this field passing itself as the Runnable target and then, starts the Thread. In a simple way, this method starts the GameEngine updating, rendering, and drawing loop.

run

public void run()
This method is the heart of the GameEngine. It's invoked by the animator.start() method in GameEngine.startEngine(). It implements the run() method from the implementing Runnable interface making the updating rendering and drawing stages to execute continuosly by the animator Thread until a control boolean variable running is set to false. The method initializes a few local variables to control the time that the loop iteration takes, in order to accurate the period interval. When one loop iteration finishes, a sleepTime value is calculated as here follows: sleepTime = (period - timeDiff) - overSleepTime; If the iteration loop takes less time than the desired period (that means the sleepTime > 0 ) the animator Thread will sleep a while giving a chance to other processes or Threads to execute (The Garbage Collector, for example). If the iteration loop has taken more time than the period (sleepTime > 0), then the excess interval is stored and the delay count is incremented. If it reaches the numberOfDelaysPerYield value, then Thread.yield() is invoked to give a chance to other Threads to execute.

Specified by:
run in interface java.lang.Runnable
See Also:
gameUpdate(), gameRender(), gameDraw()

addNotify

public void addNotify()
This method overrides it's superClass (Jpanel) addNotify(). It actually calls to super.addNotify() and GameEngine.startEngine(). That means that the GameEngine loop will start running when it's added to it's parent JComponent.

Overrides:
addNotify in class javax.swing.JComponent

showEngineStatus

public void showEngineStatus()
This method sets the showingEngineStatus field to true, making the GameEngine instance keep showing it's status.

hideEngineStatus

public void hideEngineStatus()
This method sets the showingEngineStatus field to false, making the GameEngine instance keep not showing it's status.

This method returns the maximum number of frames that the GameEngine is allowed to skip if the iteration loop exceeds the period.

maxFrameSkips - the number of frames that GameEngine can skip

setUpdatablesToOutDated

public void setUpdatablesToOutDated()
This method tells the GameEngine that its updatables are outdated. Doing that wil cause the updatables to update at the next updating stage.

setRenderablesToOutDated

public void setRenderablesToOutDated()
This method tells the GameEngine that its renderables are outdated. Doing that wil cause the renderables to update at the next rendering stage.

addGameController

public void addGameController(GameControler gameController)
This method adds a GameControler instance to the GameEngine. If another GameControler instance was previously added, this method does nothing.

Parameters:
gameController - - the desired non null GameControler instance.

terminate

public void terminate()
This method causes the updating rendering and drawing loop finish at the end of the current iteration.

testRun

public void testRun()
This method is used for internal Testing purposes, you shouldn't use it.
